awd_titl_txt: Preparing a 21st Century STEM Workforce: Defining & Measuring Leadership in Engineering Education
awd_abstract_narration:
This project aims to address the gap in understanding of how leadership competency is defined, developed, and measured in engineering undergraduates.  Specifically, the goals are to: 1) investigate the definition of leadership as defined by engineering students, faculty, and industry; 2) develop a theoretical model of leadership development as perceived by undergraduate engineering students and faculty; 3) develop a survey instrument to measure leadership capacity and efficacy in engineering; and 4) collect and analyze data with an eye toward evaluating differences between or among major, gender, socio-economic status, generational status, and ethnicity.   The impact of this project is the enabling of measurement of leadership competencies among engineers on a continuum from first year undergraduate students through graduation and into their careers as practicing engineers.  The results of this project can be used to inform evidence-based curricular and co-curricular activities, policies and practices in engineering programs to improve the nation's capacity to prepare students in STEM careers.

The project uses a multilevel, multiphase, multi-institutional, mixed methodology to: 1) generate a clear definition of engineering leadership from the perspectives of undergraduate students and faculty in engineering, ABET, and National Academy Engineering, and the construction industry; 2) develop a theoretical model describing leadership development among undergraduate engineering students; and 3) produce and pilot test an instrument to measure leadership competency (i.e., efficacy, capacity, and mastery) across a continuum from undergraduate engineering students to practicing professionals. The research plan is grounded in theories from engineering education and leadership studies and builds on the project team's previous work in producing a meta-synthesis of leadership in engineering.  To address the interconnected outcomes, this project uses the following methods: three-round Delphi Study, Q-Sort, deductive analysis, a seven-step survey development protocol and grounded theory methods.

por.por_cntn:
Leadership competency is expected in engineering on an individual level for employment and career advancement and on an industry level to address the complex and interrelated challenges facing the profession. However, undergraduate engineering students enter the workforce underprepared to lead in the ways that their employers expect. Given the lack of a clear definition of leadership in engineering and the demand for engineers to have technical depth and boundary-crossing breadth, there is a need for a comprehensive framework of leadership in engineering education and practice. 

Purpose of this project was to define, develop, and measure leadership competency in engineering. Specific goals included conceptualizing leadership from the perspective of engineering students, faculty, and industry; developing a model of undergraduate engineering students? leadership development; and creating an instrument measuring engineering students? leadership confidence, motivation, skill, and power.   

Findings from a meta-synthetic literature review indicated engineering leadership is defined as leader-centric and lacks a broader ecosystem focus. Project employed a mixed-methods approach to conceptualize and measure leadership as a value-laden set of professional competencies that operate in an ecosystem and through a relational process. We developed an online survey that collected 1,100 student responses to understand undergraduate students? perspectives and experiences related to leadership. Following these results, we conducted interviews with 15 undergraduate civil engineering students and 13 engineering faculty members. Based on the interview findings, we developed an instrument to measure undergraduate engineering students? leadership confidence, motivation, skill, and power. We collected 303 responses for the first distribution of the instrument and 125 responses for the second distribution of the revised instrument. 

Civil engineering education is the principal discipline in this project where results were found in the following areas:

Competency-based Definition of Leadership 

Study engaged with construction industry executives to identify the necessary leadership competencies for workforce entry. Through a multi-phase consensus building process, this work identified 19 competencies that highlighted the importance of interpersonal and intrapersonal knowledge, skills, and attributes. This framework provides a more expansive conceptualization of leadership that is situated within construction to inform how leadership is developed in education and practice. 

Undergraduate Students? Leadership Definition and Development

Project took a mixed methods approach to understanding undergraduate engineering students? definition of leadership and leadership development. Students? conceptualization of leadership formed primarily outside of the classroom-- through extracurricular and co-curricular activities, work experiences, and family backgrounds. Students perceived that within the technical engineering curriculum, there were few opportunities to learn about nontechnical competencies, including leadership. There was a dichotomy in the interview sample regarding whether leadership could be developed in these settings or whether it was an innate attribute. This work highlighted the need to intentionally and comprehensively integrate leadership in engineering education, in part to provide more opportunities for development and to mitigate the messages in the hidden curriculum that only certain people can be leaders.    

Instrument Development

Synthesis of survey results and interview findings resulted in the development of a novel instrument measuring perceptions of power, leadership as a shared process, transformational leadership skill, self-efficacy, and motivation. Instrument combines validated constructs to explore how engineering undergraduate students understand and engage with leadership in team settings. 

Competency Development 

Implications of this work highlight the various ways through which students conceptualize and develop nontechnical competencies. Interplay between technical, professional, interpersonal, and intrapersonal competencies enable engineering leadership. Research also highlighted the importance of out-of-class activities and mentors in accessing leadership-developing opportunities. However, these opportunities, and the social capital needed to activate them, were not equally distributed. It is thus critical to broaden participation in internships, out-of-class activities, and mentorship networks to all engineering students while also improving opportunities for leadership development in the classroom where all students have access. 

Integrated Findings

Study pointed to the various ways through which students come to conceptualize and practice leadership. Making explicit students? long-held beliefs about leadership, understanding how and where students develop leadership competence and self-efficacy, building awareness around students? access to social capital for leadership-building opportunities, and examining differences by demographics inform educators and administrators in how to support engineering students in becoming leaders and being prepared for the expectations of the workforce.

IM/BI

This project advances the understanding of engineering leadership in education and practice by synthesizing the perspectives of industry executives, undergraduate students, and faculty members. This research contributes a framework of leadership-coupled professional competencies; results in strategies to support students? workforce preparation through leadership efficacy; provides a survey instrument that can be used in universities to gain a profile of students? leadership; and informs research communities, policymakers, and administrators.  

Research on leadership competence and development is essential to preparing the workforce for the complex, interconnected challenges facing our global industry. Understanding how leadership is defined, taught, and enabled in engineering can support educators, administrators, and practitioners in providing pathways and opportunities for students to develop these critical competencies.
